questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with unilateral hearing loss. The audiogram is shown above. Which sign is most likely to be present in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hitzelberger sign

 

The audiogram shows a gradually sloping sensorineural hearing loss pattern with worse hearing at higher frequencies, characteristic of acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma). This pattern differs from Carhart's notch seen in otosclerosis. The absence of an air-bone gap and the unilateral nature suggests a retrocochlear pathology.

 

Hitzelberger sign, characterized by hypesthesia of the posterior wall of external auditory canal due to involvement of auricular branch of vagus nerve, is a pathognomonic sign of acoustic neuroma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Balance sign: This is a non-specific term referring to vestibular function tests and is not a characteristic sign of any particular pathology.

 

Option B. Hennebert sign: This is a positive pressure-induced nystagmus seen in labyrinthine fistula, typically associated with chronic otitis media, not acoustic neuroma.

 

Option D. Gradenigo sign: This refers to the triad of abducens nerve palsy, facial pain, and otitis media seen in petrous apicitis. It is not associated with acoustic neuroma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the audiometric pattern of acoustic neuroma (gradual high-frequency SNHL) and its associated clinical sign (Hitzelberger sign) is crucial for diagnosis. The lack of air-bone gap differentiates it from otosclerosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with a firm, tender, slow-growing mass below the ear as shown in the image below. What could be the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid abscess

 

  • The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of a parotid abscess.
  • It is suppuration of the parotid space. Deep cervical fascia splits into two layers, superficial and deep, to enclose the parotid gland and its associated structures. Parotid space lies deep to its superficial layer.
  • Dehydration, particularly in postsurgical cases and debilitated patients, with stasis of salivary flow is the predisposing cause.
  • Most common organism- Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Presents with unilateral swelling associated with redness, induration, and tenderness over the parotid gland and angle of the mandible. Dehydration and fever are also present.
  • Investigations -
    • Diagnosis is by ultrasonography or a CT scan – to know extent of abscess
    • Aspiration of abscess for culture and sensitivity to isolate causative organism
  • Treatment -
    • Surgical drainage of the abscess is done via a preauricular incision along with IV antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold abscess: is a complication of mastoiditis which presents as swelling in upper part of neck when pus breaks inferiorly, through the tip of the mastoid

 

Option C. Upper cervical lymphadenopathy: occurs in the neck region following infection in the area drained by these structures.

 

Option D. Osteoma of the mandible: characterized by a benign, slow-growing tumor on the mandible, which is usually painless and asymptomatic, not presenting with tenderness and acute symptoms like an abscess.

 

Educational Objective:


Diagnosing and treating a parotid abscess promptly is crucial to prevent further complications such as the spread of infection. The characteristic presentation of swelling, tenderness, and systemic signs in a specific location aids in differential diagnosis from other potential conditions affecting the neck and jaw area.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 297

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presented with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and blood-tinged nasal discharge. His CT scan is given. What could be the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Maxillary Sinus Carcinoma

 

Explanation: 

 

The patient presents with symptoms including nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and blood-tinged nasal discharge. The CT scan shows a mass involving the maxillary sinus. These clinical features are highly suggestive of maxillary sinus carcinoma. This condition often presents with such symptoms due to the tumor mass causing obstruction and local invasion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma: This condition typically occurs in adolescent males and arises from the nasopharynx, not the maxillary sinus. It is characterized by severe epistaxis and nasal obstruction, but the patient's age and the location of the mass make this diagnosis unlikely.

 

 

Option C. Orbital Floor Fracture: Orbital floor fractures are best seen in coronal CT views and typically result from trauma. They present with symptoms such as diplopia, enophthalmos, and infraorbital anesthesia, but not with nasal obstruction and cheek swelling without trauma history.

 

Option D. Rhinocerebral Mucormycosis: This condition is seen in immunocompromised patients, such as those with uncontrolled diabetes. It involves rapid tissue destruction, including the eyes and palate, leading to black necrotic tissue. The presentation of the patient does not fit this severe and aggressive infection.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maxillary sinus carcinoma presents with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and blood-tinged nasal discharge. Diagnosis is often confirmed through imaging, showing a mass in the maxillary sinus

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss. On otoscopic examination, a reddish mass is seen behind the tympanic membrane. CT scan shows an enhancing mass with intact caroticojugular spine, and the lesion appears to be confined to the mesotympanum. (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glomus tympanicum

 

The presence of a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane with an intact caroticojugular spine and confinement to the mesotympanum is characteristic of a glomus tympanicum tumor. Unlike glomus jugulare, these tumors:

 

  • Arise from paraganglionic tissue along the tympanic branch of CN IX (Jacobson's nerve)
  • Are confined to the middle ear cavity
  • Do not erode the jugular bulb or caroticojugular spine
  • Present earlier with hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus
  • Have better surgical outcomes due to their limited extent

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glomus jugulare: Incorrect because these tumors show erosion of the jugular bulb and absent caroticojugular spine (felp sign), which is not seen in this case.

 

Option C. Cholesterol granuloma: This appears as a cystic lesion with characteristic high signal on both T1 and T2 MRI sequences, not as a vascular mass.

 

Option D. Meningioma: These are usually not pulsatile and appear as a soft tissue mass with associated hyperostosis or calcification.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To differentiate between glomus tympanicum and jugulare based on the integrity of the caroticojugular spine (felp sign) and extent of tumor, which guides surgical approach and prognosis.

questions.text: A nasal endoscopy image shows a septal perforation in a patient following nasal surgery done 3 months ago. Preoperative CT scan showed extensive bilateral concha bullosa which was addressed surgically. Which surgery is the most likely cause of this perforation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FESS

 

In cases of extensive concha bullosa requiring surgical intervention, FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery) with lateral lamellectomy is performed. During this procedure, if excessive force is used or there's inadequate visualization while removing the lateral lamella of the middle turbinate, it can damage the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid (a part of the nasal septum). The healing process in this area, particularly if there's bilateral damage, can result in septal perforation. This risk is heightened when bilateral concha bullosa is addressed simultaneously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SMR: While SMR historically has a higher risk of septal perforation due to complete removal of septal cartilage, it's not typically performed when the primary pathology is concha bullosa.

 

Option C. Septoplasty: Although septoplasty can cause septal perforation, it's not the primary surgery indicated for concha bullosa. Moreover, modern septoplasty techniques preserve mucoperichondrial flaps and replace cartilage, reducing perforation risk.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as FESS is a recognized cause of septal perforation, especially in cases involving bilateral middle turbinate surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During FESS for bilateral concha bullosa, careful surgical technique is essential as aggressive resection or poor visualization can lead to septal damage and subsequent perforation, particularly when operating on both sides of the nasal cavity

questions.text: CT scan of a patient with laryngeal carcinoma is shown below. Single ipsilateral < 3cm node is seen. What is the staging? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. T4N1M0

The given CT image is consistent with a staging of T4N1M0. It depicts a large glottic-subglottic mass with massive cricoid and thyroid invasion and extra laryngeal spread indicating a T4 stage.

Above shown is CT scan of a 72-year-old patient with T4a laryngeal cancer (red arrows) showing a large extralaryngeal extension through the left side of the thyroid cartilage. Indication of primary total laryngectomy.

Other Options:

Option A. T1N0M0: Would indicate a tumor confined to one subsite with no lymph node involvement or distant metastasis, which does not correlate with the extensive involvement shown in the image.

Option C. T2N1M0: Suggests tumor involvement of adjacent subsites or impaired vocal cord mobility, which is less extensive than that shown.

Option D. T3N0M0: Indicates more advanced local disease than T2 but without the extensive extra-laryngeal spread or significant lymph node involvement shown in the image.

Educational Objective:

TNM STAGING FOR CA LARYNX:

T1 – Only 1 subsite (supraglottis/glottis/subglottis)

T2 – Involves adjacent subsites or sites, impaired vocal cord mobility.

T3 – Involving Pre-epiglottic space & post-cricoid area, fixed vocal cords.

T4a – Local invasion through thyroid cartilage or tissues beyond larynx

T4b – Invasion to distant places (prevertebral space, mediastinum, carotid, etc)

N0 – No cervical lymph nodes

N1 – Single ipsilateral < 3cm

N2 – Single ipsilateral 3-6cm / multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral < 6cm

N3 – Single or multiple nodes > 6cm

M0 – No metastasis

M1 – Metastasis present

Ref: Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 348

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with chronic otitis media presents with hearing loss. On otoscopic examination, there is significant tympanosclerosis with calcific plaques but no perforation. During evaluation, a Rinne test is performed. What would be the expected outcome of the Rinne test? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Positive

 

Tympanosclerosis without perforation typically causes minimal conductive hearing loss due to stiffening of the tympanic membrane, but the air-bone gap is usually less than 30 dB. In such cases, the Rinne test remains positive because air conduction is still better than bone conduction. This is different from cases with frank perforation where a negative Rinne test would be expected. The calcific plaques in tympanosclerosis may affect membrane mobility but don't completely disrupt the conduction mechanism like a perforation would.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Negative: A negative Rinne test occurs when there is a significant conductive hearing loss with an air-bone gap greater than 30 dB, typically seen in conditions like tympanic membrane perforation or ossicular chain disruption, which isn't the case here.

 

Option C. Indeterminate: This is not a standard result for the Rinne test. The test yields either positive or negative results based on the comparison between air and bone conduction.

 

Option D. Equivocal: An equivocal result is not a standard outcome of the Rinne test. The test should clearly demonstrate whether air or bone conduction is better perceived.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tympanosclerosis without perforation typically causes mild conductive hearing loss with an air-bone gap less than 30 dB, resulting in a positive Rinne test, unlike tympanic membrane perforation which causes a negative Rinne test due to more significant conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient with diabetes arrived at the clinic with a concerning issue - a black, malodorous discharge originating from her nose. Upon examination, it was discovered that the nasal cavity contained a dark necrotic mass, which had caused erosion of both the septum and hard palate. What could be the most likely diagnosis for this condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucormycosis

 

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Mucormycosis.

 

It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.

 

PATHOLOGY – From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain. The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES – Black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.

 

DIAGNOSIS – Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections.

 

Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast MRI.

 

TREATMENT – Amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillosis: While Aspergillosis can also present with sinus involvement, it generally does not cause the rapidly progressive and destructive changes typical of mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Foreign Body: Would not typically lead to rapid tissue necrosis unless secondarily infected, and does not generally produce the black necrotic tissue associated with fungal infections.

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis: Caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi; presents with polypoid masses in the nasal passage, distinct from the necrotic presentation of mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis should be considered a medical emergency in immunocompromised patients presenting with signs of rapid, invasive sinus infection. Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are crucial to improve survival rates in affected individuals.

choices.text: It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases
It shows Ad type of curve

questions.text: A patient has otitis media with effusion. Which of the following is wrong?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It shows Ad type of curve

 

Otitis media with effusion (OME) is a condition characterized by the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs or symptoms of acute ear infection. The incorrect statement regarding it is, It shows Ad type of curve. This statement is incorrect. OME typically shows a B type of tympanogram curve. A B type curve indicates the presence of middle ear fluid. An Ad type curve is associated with ossicular discontinuity, which is not related to OME.

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bilateral: Can be true but not mandatory; OME can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Option B. It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases: True, as the condition often resolves with the resolution of the underlying URTI.

 

Option C. It is associated with cold: True, as URTI and colds can lead to Eustachian tube dysfunction and subsequent fluid accumulation in the middle ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otitis media with effusion shows a B type of tympanogram curve, not an Ad type curve.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with hearing loss and tinnitus. A histology image is shown below. What can be the diagnosis for this patient?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schwannoma

 

The given clinical scenario and histology image showing Verocay bodies are suggestive of Schwannoma /Acoustic neuroma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibroma is a benign tumor that develops along nerve cells. Histology image shows wreath like multinucleated giant cells.

 

 

Option B. Leiomyoma on histology shows well-differentiated, regular, spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with hyalinization.

 

 

Option D. Rhabdomyoma on microscopy shows enlarged myocytes with abundant glycogen. Post-processing, glycogen content gets reduced and look like thin strands.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannoma is a benign tumor often associated with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, diagnosed via characteristic histological patterns and confirmed with MRI. It requires careful management, sometimes involving advanced surgical techniques such as Gamma Knife surgery.

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auricular branch of vagus

 

Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (also called Arnold's nerve).

 

Nerve supply of external auditory canal

 

External Auditory Canal

 

  1. Anterior wall and roof: auriculotemporal (V3).
  2. Posterior wall and floor: auricular branch of vagus (CN X) aka Arnolds nerve
  3. Posterior wall of the auditory canal also receives sensory fibres of CN VII through auricular branch of vagus

 

Ear-cough reflex (Otorespiratory reflex): Stimulation of Arnold's nerve in the external auditory canal during wax removal evokes reflex cough.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve - Provides sensation to the anterior wall and roof of the canal, not typically associated with triggering cough.

 

Option C. Great auricular nerve - Primarily involved in the sensation of the skin around the ear, not the inner canal.

 

Option D. Facial nerve - While it contributes sensory fibers, it is not the primary cause of the cough reflex in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ear-cough reflex is a unique physiological reaction mediated by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve, illustrating the interconnectedness of sensory pathways and autonomic responses in the human body.

questions.text: Which perspective provides the clearest view of the frontal sinus? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Caldwell’s view

 

The Caldwell view is a caudally angled radiograph, with its posteroanterior projection allowing for minimal radiation to the orbits.

 

The rays pass from behind the head and are angled at 15-20° to the radiographic plate. It is commonly used to get better view of the ethmoid and frontal sinuses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Towne's View: Primarily used for examining the foramen magnum at the base of the skull, not ideal for sinus examination.

 

Option C. Law's View: Typically used for visualizing the mastoid air cells, not the frontal sinuses.

 

Option D. Stenver's View: Used for imaging the internal auditory canal and cochlea, not related to sinus imaging

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Stenver’s view is done for cochlear implants.

 

 

  • Law’s view is used to assess mastoid air cells.

 

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493, 494

questions.text: What is the maneuver depicted in the image given below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trotter’s method

 

The image shows Trotter's method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step to control epistaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epley's maneuver: Is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).

 

 

Option C. Mc Govern technique: A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway. It is used as an emergency management may be required in bilateral choanal atresia to provide an airway.

 

 

Option D. Valsalva maneuver: A technique where the patient forcefully exhales while keeping the mouth and nose closed. This increases intrathoracic pressure and is used in various medical situations, including adjusting ear pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trotter’s method is an effective first-line intervention for controlling epistaxis. It emphasizes maintaining an upright, forward-leaning posture to minimize blood swallowing and facilitate proper drainage, essential for patient comfort and safety during a nosebleed episode.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No.  183, 199

choices.text: Both Vocal cords involved and fixed
Both Vocal cords involved and mobile
One Vocal cord involved and fixed
One Vocal cord involved and mobile

questions.text: Mark the correct description for laryngeal cancer stage T1b N0 M0.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both vocal cords involved and mobile

 

T1b in Laryngeal Cancer refers to the tumor involving both vocal cords but still maintaining mobility. This indicates that the cancer is localized to the vocal cords without extending into other areas that would restrict their movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Both Vocal cords involved and fixed: This would typically be classified under T3 or higher, depending on the extent of fixation and additional features.

 

Option C. One Vocal cord involved and fixed: Would be classified as T3 due to the fixation of the vocal cord, indicating more advanced local disease.

 

Option D. One Vocal cord involved and mobile: This corresponds to T1a, indicating a more limited disease confined to one vocal cord but not affecting mobility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TNM staging for CA Larynx:

 

  • T1 – only 1 subsite (supraglottis/glottis/subglottis)
  • T2 – involves adjacent subsites or sites, impaired vocal cord mobility.
  • T3 – involving pre-epiglottic space & post-cricoid area, fixed vocal cords.
  • T4a – local invasion through thyroid cartilage or tissues beyond larynx
  • T4b – Invasion to distant places (prevertebral space, mediastinum, carotid, etc)
  • N0 – no cervical lymph nodes
  • N1 – single ipsilateral < 3cm
  • N2 – single ipsilateral 3-6cm / multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral < 6cm
  • N3 – single or multiple nodes > 6cm
  • M0 – no metastasis
  • M1 – metastasis present

questions.text: What is absent in a case of otitis media among the options provided? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Battle's sign

 

Battle's sign, characterized by ecchymosis (bruising) over the mastoid process, is typically indicative of a basilar skull fracture, specifically fractures involving the temporal bone. It is not associated with otitis media, which is an infection or inflammation of the middle ear.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold abscess: This abscess is a serious complication of otitis media. It occurs when the infection spreads from the mastoid process into the surrounding tissues, leading to a collection of pus.

Option B. Griesinger's sign: This sign is associated with lateral sinus thrombosis, a rare but severe complication of otitis media and mastoiditis. It involves tenderness and swelling behind the ear and along the mastoid bone.

Option D. Delta sign: Also related to lateral sinus thrombosis, the Delta sign typically appears on contrast-enhanced imaging studies as a NON enhancement at thrombosed area of sinus, a complication arising from otitis media.

Educational Objective:

 

While otitis media can lead to various complications, including Bezold abscess and lateral sinus thrombosis (indicated by Griesinger’s sign and Delta sign), Battle's sign is not associated with this condition. Instead, Battle's sign should prompt an evaluation for temporal bone fractures, emphasizing the importance of distinguishing between signs of infection and trauma.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 87, 93, 507

questions.text:
What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image?

(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
✅ Correct Answer: B. Grade 2

📸 Image Analysis:

The otoscopic image shows a retracted pars tensa where deeper middle ear structures like the long process of the incus and incudostapedial joint are visible. The lateral process of the malleus is prominently seen, and the tympanic membrane appears pulled medially, but it is not adherent to the promontory, and air is still visible in the middle ear. This presentation is typical of Grade 2 retraction.

🔍 Explanation of Options:

Option A: Grade 1

In Grade 1 pars tensa retraction, there is only mild inward retraction. The cone of light is lost, the fibrous annulus appears more prominent, and the handle of the malleus becomes more medialized. Importantly, there is no contact with the ossicles, and ossicular landmarks like the incus are not visible. This does not match the findings seen in the image.

 

Option B: Grade 2

Grade 2 retraction is more severe than Grade 1, and the pars tensa is retracted to the extent that it touches the long process of the incus. Deeper structures like the incudostapedial joint, round window niche, and even the horizontal facial canal may be visible. The tympanic membrane still retains some mobility and is not adherent to the promontory. This fits the otoscopic image exactly, where ossicular structures are seen but no signs of complete adhesion are present.

 

Option C: Grade 3

In Grade 3 retraction, the tympanic membrane is severely retracted and becomes adherent to the promontory, forming what is called an atelectatic membrane. Although some air may still remain in the middle ear, the drum is essentially collapsed onto the medial wall. This condition is more advanced than what is seen in the current image.

 

Option D: Grade 4

This is the most severe stage where the entire tympanic membrane is stuck to the promontory, and there is complete loss of middle ear aeration. It often leads to adhesive otitis media, and ossicular erosion (such as necrosis of the incus) may occur. This is clearly not the case here, as ossicles are intact and the membrane is not fully adherent.

🧠 Educational Objective:

Grade 2 pars tensa retraction is identified when the tympanic membrane retracts to touch the long process of the incus without adhering to the promontory, often revealing middle ear ossicles such as the incudostapedial joint.

questions.text: Identify the blocked structure. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinus

 

The image shows a coronal CT scan of the sinuses, where a blocked structure is indicated by the arrow. The blockage appears to be in the maxillary sinus, which is characterized by the presence of an antrochoanal polyp. Antrochoanal polyps originate in the maxillary sinus and extend into the nasal cavity, typically passing through the middle meatus. In this case, the blockage is in the maxillary sinus, as evidenced by the extension of the polyp towards the middle meatus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ethmoid sinus: This is incorrect because the ethmoid sinus is located medially and superiorly to the maxillary sinus and does not match the position of the blockage shown in the image.

  

Option C. Frontal sinus: This is incorrect as the frontal sinus is located above the eyes and towards the forehead, which is not indicated as blocked in the image.

 Option D. Sphenoid sinus: This is incorrect because the sphenoid sinus is located deeper within the skull, behind the ethmoid sinuses, and is not the blocked area shown.

    

Educational Objective:

 

The maxillary sinus can be blocked by an antrochoanal polyp that extends into the nasal cavity through the middle meatus.

questions.text: All of the following are major diagnostic criteria for allergic fungal sinusitis except? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Positive fungal culture

 

A positive fungal culture is a minor diagnostic criterion for allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

 

This classification was detailed by Bent and Kuhn, who established criteria based on their findings of several clinical features important for the diagnosis of AFRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of nasal polyps: Polyps are a common and significant finding in AFRS, often contributing to the blockage and symptoms of sinusitis.

 

Option B. Eosinophilic mucin: A hallmark of AFRS, this refers to thick, peanut butter-like mucin with eosinophils.

 

Option C. Characteristic CT findings: These include hyperdense areas within the sinuses, which are indicative of fungal involvement and mucin accumulation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bent and Kuhn described a diagnostic criterion for AFRS. They found 11 important clinical features, 5 of which were termed major criteria and the remaining 6 features as minor criteria. These criteria includes:

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, Volume 1, Page No. 1049

choices.text: Point of maximum tension in a fracture
Collagen and elastin lines in stab injury

questions.text: What are Kraissl’s lines?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Relaxed tension lines in skin

 

Kraissl’s lines, also known as relaxed skin tension lines (RSTLs), are lines on the skin that indicate the natural orientation of the skin under minimal or no tension. They are used in surgical planning, particularly in cosmetic surgery, to guide incisions so that they heal with the least visible scars. Kraissl’s lines differ from Langer's lines, which also describe lines of skin tension but are based on the alignment of collagen fibers within the dermis and are typically used to predict surgical wound healing outcomes.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point of maximum tension in a fracture: Refers to the area where the mechanical stress is greatest on a broken bone, unrelated to skin tension lines.

 

Option C. Collagen and elastin lines in stab injury: Would refer to the orientation of these fibers in response to a penetrating trauma, which is not what Kraissl’s lines describe.

 

Option D. Point of tension in hanging: Refers to the mechanical stress points exerted during a hanging, specifically on the neck, which has no relation to the relaxed skin tension lines described by Kraissl.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Kraissl’s lines are crucial for surgical incision planning to ensure scars are minimally visible following healing, highlighting the importance of understanding skin tension dynamics in medical procedures.

questions.text: Please identify the retractor depicted in the image below:(INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mollison's mastoid retractor

 

  • The instrument shown in the above image is Mollison's mastoid retractor.
  • It is used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Joll's retractor is used in thyroid surgery. It is self-retaining retractor.

 

 

Option B. Perkins retractor is used to open small incisions with minimal damage to surrounding tissues.

 

 

Option D. Langenbeck retractor is used to hold back, edges of incisions, tissue or organs

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mollison's Mastoid retractor is specifically tailored for ear surgeries, particularly mastoidectomy, where precise and sustained retraction of soft tissues is crucial. Understanding the specific applications and features of various retractors enhances surgical efficiency and safety.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge along with the following CT scan. On suction cleaning, there is thick mucin that contains eosinophils, Charcot-Leyden crystals. What would be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Allergic fungal sinusitis

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge. The presence of thick mucin containing eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals, as well as the CT findings, are indicative of allergic fungal sinusitis (AFS). AFS is characterized by the accumulation of eosinophils and allergic mucin in the sinuses, often resulting in hyperdensities on CT scans.

 

Treatment is always surgical exploration (removal of fungal mass)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fungal Ball: A fungal ball, or mycetoma, typically involves a single sinus (commonly the maxillary sinus) and appears as a mass of fungal elements without significant allergic mucin or eosinophils. It does not usually present with eosinophils or Charcot-Leyden crystals in the discharge.

 

Option C. Chronic rhinosinusitis: Chronic rhinosinusitis involves prolonged inflammation of the sinuses but does not specifically present with the eosinophilic mucin and Charcot-Leyden crystals seen in AFS. The CT findings in chronic rhinosinusitis do not typically show the hyperdensities seen in AFS.

 

Option D. Fulminant fungal sinusitis: Fulminant fungal sinusitis is a rapidly progressive infection seen in immunocompromised patients and involves extensive bony destruction and tissue invasion. The CT scan would show significant bone destruction and possibly extension into adjacent structures, which is not evident in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic fungal sinusitis is characterized by unilateral nasal obstruction, thick mucin containing eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals, and hyperdensities on CT scans, without extensive bony destruction.

questions.text: For newborn hearing screening purpose, which test is most commonly used? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) OAE

 

Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) is the most commonly used test for newborn hearing screening. OAE testing is a simple, quick, and non-invasive method that measures sounds (emissions) produced by the inner ear (cochlea) in response to an auditory stimulus. This test is highly effective for detecting hearing loss in newborns and can be performed shortly after birth. If the OAE test results are normal, no further testing is needed. However, if the OAE test is abnormal, further evaluation with Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is recommended after three months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BERA: Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is used if OAE results are abnormal. It is more comprehensive but not used as the initial screening test due to its complexity and requirement for specialized equipment.

 

Option C. PTA: Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) is not suitable for newborns as it requires behavioral responses to sound, which cannot be reliably obtained from newborns.

 

Option D. Impedance: Impedance audiometry measures the function of the middle ear but is not used for initial newborn hearing screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) testing is the standard and most commonly used initial screening method for detecting hearing loss in newborns due to its simplicity, quick results, and effectiveness.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with left-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis. On examination, a vascular mass is seen filling the left nasal cavity. CT shows a mass extending to the nasopharynx with anterior bowing of the posterior wall of maxillary sinus (Holman-Miller sign). The surgical approach shown in the image would be most appropriate for: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Midfacial degloving

 

The image shows a transcolumellar incision which, when combined with bilateral intercartilaginous and transfixion incisions, forms part of the midfacial degloving approach. This approach is ideal for:
 

  • Large nasopharyngeal tumors (like juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma)
  • Avoiding external facial scars
  • Providing wide exposure of midface structures
  • Allowing bilateral access to sinonasal cavity
  • Better cosmetic outcome compared to lateral rhinotomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open rhinoplasty: While the incision is similar, open rhinoplasty alone would not provide adequate exposure for a extensive nasopharyngeal tumor.

 

Option C. Weber-Ferguson incision: This leaves visible facial scars and is more extensive than needed for most sinonasal tumors.

 

Option D. Lateral rhinotomy: Creates visible facial scarring and provides more limited access compared to midfacial degloving.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To recognize that while similar incisions may be used in different approaches, the complete surgical approach is chosen based on the pathology's extent and location. Midfacial degloving combines cosmetically favorable incisions with excellent exposure for nasopharyngeal tumors.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myringotomy

 

Myringotomy is done by a sharp myringotome as shown in the image. Myringotome is a surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum.

 

Myringotomy is most commonly done for serous otitis media in the anteroinferior quadrant radially. Sometimes, grommet insertion is done through the opening made by myringotome in the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septoplasty: This procedure corrects a deviated nasal septum, involving different instruments primarily for reshaping the nasal structure, not for ear-related surgeries.

 

Option B. Myringoplasty: This is a procedure to repair a perforation of the tympanic membrane but does not typically use a myringotome; instead, it uses tools for patching or grafting the membrane.

 

Option D. Adenoidectomy: This surgery involves the removal of the adenoids located in the upper part of the throat behind the nose, using different instruments like curettes or microdebriders, not a myringotome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The myringotome is crucial for performing a myringotomy, allowing for precise incisions in the tympanic membrane to address issues such as serous otitis media. The instrument's design facilitates targeted, clean cuts to insert grommets if needed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Earache

 

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

 

Tuberculosis of the ear

 

Aetiology - Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

Pathology - The process is slow and insidious. Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of middle ear cleft and caseate. There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Multiple perforations may form which coalesce to form a single large perforation. Middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.

 

Clinical features - Painless foul smelling ear discharge, multiple perforations, hearing loss. Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with formation of bony sequestra are often seen in these cases.

 

Treatment - Antitubercular treatment + Mastoidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple perforations - A characteristic feature of the disease, representing advanced tissue damage.

 

Option C. Pale granulation - These are typical findings within the affected structures.

 

Option D. Foul smelling ear discharge - A hallmark symptom of tubercular otitis media due to the extensive necrosis and infection.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

 

Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 81

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presents with dysarthria, deviation of uvula, and difficulty swallowing liquids. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vagus nerve

 

The clinical presentation suggests vagus nerve (CN X) palsy. The cardinal features of:

  • Dysarthria (nasal speech)
  • Uvular deviation (away from the affected side)
  • Dysphagia (especially for liquids) are characteristic of vagus nerve dysfunction.

 

The vagus nerve provides motor innervation to the soft palate, pharynx, and larynx through its pharyngeal and laryngeal branches. When affected, it causes:

 

  1. Paralysis of soft palate causing nasal regurgitation
  2. Deviation of uvula to the healthy side
  3. Impaired swallowing reflex
  4. Voice changes due to vocal cord paralysis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve: While it can affect taste and cause facial weakness, it doesn't cause uvular deviation or significant dysphagia.

 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve: Primarily provides sensory innervation to face and motor supply to muscles of mastication. Doesn't affect uvula or pharyngeal function.

 

Option C. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Though involved in swallowing, isolated glossopharyngeal palsy is rare and wouldn't cause uvular deviation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the clinical features of vagal nerve palsy is crucial as it can be a presentation of various conditions including diabetic neuropathy, skull base tumors, or brainstem pathology. The key diagnostic features are uvular deviation, palatal weakness, and dysphagia.

questions.text: A patient complains that he feels like the room is spinning when he gets up from lying down or turning his head. He has no history of loss of consciousness. Which of the following could be the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).
  • BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals (otoconia) usually dislodged from the utricle. These otoconia will enter the semicircular canal and will cause change in the density of the endolymphatic fluid as well as they will inadvertently touch the cupula and cause unnecessary stimulation of the hair cells in cristae.
  • Epley's maneuver is performed to reposition the crystals into the utricle from the semicircular canals. This is only a temporary cure and there is a high rate of recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meniere's disease: Presents with recurrent spontaneous vertigo episodes lasting for hours associated by aural fullness, tinnitus and hearing loss.

 

Option C. Labyrinthitis: Presents with severe, sudden-onset, spontaneous vertigo which is continuous and associated with hearing loss, nausea and vomiting.

 

Option D. Syncope is defined as a transient, self-limited loss of consciousness with an inability to maintain postural tone that is followed by spontaneous recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not typically seen in allergic rhinitis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otto veraguth folds

Allergic rhinitis is a condition characterized by symptoms such as sneezing, nasal congestion, runny nose, and itchy eyes. These symptoms can lead to several physical signs due to chronic inflammation and repetitive actions like rubbing the nose and eyes. However we do not see Otto Veraguth folds in Allergic Rhinitis.

 Also known as Veraguth folds, these are small creases on the upper eyelid and are not related to allergic rhinitis. They are typically associated with individuals suffering from depression, not allergic conditions.

Other Options:

Option A. Allergic Shiners: Commonly seen in allergic rhinitis due to venous congestion under the eyes.

Option B. Allergic Salute: A habitual action in allergic rhinitis leading to a nasal crease.

Option D. Dennis Morgan Lines: Found in chronic allergic conditions due to persistent inflammation and edema, including allergic rhinitis.

Educational Objective: 

Otto Veraguth folds are not associated with allergic rhinitis but are more commonly seen in individuals with depression.

questions.text: An adult man in a restaurant suddenly begins choking on his food. He is conscious. The following procedure was performed. Identify the procedure: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heimlich’s maneuver

 

The image shows a Heimlich's maneuver

 

First aid for foreign body in the airway -

 

A large bolus of food obstructed above the cords may make the patient totally aphonic, unable to cry for help. He may die of asphyxia unless immediate first aid measures are taken.

 

The first aid measures consist of pounding on the back, turning the patient upside down and following Heimlich maneuver. These measures should not be done if the patient is only partially obstructed, for fear of causing total obstruction.

 

Heimlich maneuver. - Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs may dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Back Slaps: Before attempting the Heimlich maneuver, delivering five firm back slaps between the individual's shoulder blades can be tried as this may dislodge the item.

 

Option C. Chest Thrusts: Used instead of abdominal thrusts in cases where the Heimlich might be risky, such as in very obese or pregnant individuals.

 

Option D. Blind Finger Sweeps: Not recommended due to the risk of pushing the object deeper into the throat, potentially worsening the blockage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Heimlich maneuver is an effective emergency procedure for saving lives in cases of severe choking. It is important for everyone to learn this technique as it can be performed on others or even on oneself in a choking emergency.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 367

questions.text: What is the site of drainage of the marked structure? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sphenoethmoidal recess

 

The identified anatomical feature corresponds to the sphenoid sinus, which effectively empties into the Sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior meatus: This meatus drains the posterior ethmoid sinus.

 

Option B. Middle meatus: The middle meatus is the drainage site for several other sinuses, including the frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, and anterior ethmoid sinus. It is the most common drainage site for these sinuses, but not for the sphenoid sinus.

 

Option C. Inferior meatus: This meatus primarily serves as the drainage site for the nasolacrimal duct, which is responsible for draining tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity. It does not play a role in draining any of the paranasal sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 209

questions.text: A child was brought to ENT OPD with complaints of mouth breathing and snoring from a long duration. He also asks to increase the volume of TV while watching. What is the best treatment for this child’s condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adenoidectomy and grommet

 

The child presents with symptoms of mouth breathing and snoring, which are indicative of adenoid hypertrophy. The request to increase the TV volume suggests a hearing problem, likely due to conductive hearing loss caused by chronic adenoiditis with adenoid hypertrophy. Enlarged adenoids can obstruct the Eustachian tube, leading to fluid accumulation in the middle ear, known as otitis media with effusion. This condition causes conductive hearing loss.

 

Adenoidectomy involves the surgical removal of the adenoids to alleviate the obstruction. Inserting a grommet (tympanostomy tube) allows for drainage of the middle ear fluid, improving hearing and preventing recurrent otitis media.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoidectomy: While this addresses the adenoid hypertrophy, it does not address the fluid accumulation in the middle ear. The addition of a grommet is necessary for complete management.

 

Option B. Antibiotics: Antibiotics alone would not resolve the underlying issue of adenoid hypertrophy and chronic Eustachian tube obstruction.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: This approach would not be suitable given the chronic nature of the symptoms and the associated hearing loss. Delaying treatment could lead to further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of chronic adenoid hypertrophy causing mouth breathing, snoring, and conductive hearing loss, the best treatment involves adenoidectomy along with the insertion of a grommet to ensure proper drainage of middle ear fluid and restore normal hearing.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of hearing loss and can understand only shouted or amplified speech. What would be the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe hearing loss

Severe hearing loss means that individuals cannot hear most conversations. They typically only hear very loud sounds, such as a raised voice or sounds above 61 to 80 dB. They may not understand speech at normal levels and usually require powerful hearing aids or cochlear implants to assist their hearing. These individuals may rely more on lip reading or sign language.

Other Options:

Option A. Mild hearing loss: Individuals with mild hearing loss typically have difficulty understanding speech, especially in noisy situations. The hearing loss ranges between 26 and 40 decibels (dB). They can usually hear well in one-to-one conversations and might only struggle in noisier environments.

Option B. Moderate hearing loss: With moderate hearing loss, individuals have difficulty understanding regular speech, even at close distances. The hearing loss is between 41 and 60 dB. They often require some form of hearing assistance for daily activities and may benefit significantly from hearing aids.

Option D. Profound hearing loss: Profound hearing loss indicates that individuals cannot hear any speech and only very loud sounds exceeding 81 dB, such as that from heavy machinery or loud horns. Conversational speech is not audible at all. Persons with profound hearing loss rely on visual communication methods like sign language and may be candidates for cochlear implants.

Educational Objective: 

The case scenario described above points towards Severe hearing loss in the patient.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for JNA? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CECT

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular tumor found in adolescent males. The investigation of choice for JNA is Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT). CECT is preferred because it effectively delineates the bony margins and the extent of the tumor, including any bone erosion. The contrast enhancement helps in identifying the vascular nature of the tumor, which is crucial in differentiating JNA from other masses in the nasal cavity, such as adenoids or carcinomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI: MRI is helpful for assessing orbital and cranial extensions of the tumor but is not the primary choice for initial diagnosis. It does not provide as clear an image of the bony structures as CECT does.

 

Option C. DNE (Diagnostic Nasal Endoscopy): While DNE can visualize a mass in the nasal cavity, it cannot determine the type of mass or its vascular nature. It is less informative than imaging studies in the diagnosis of JNA.

 

Option D. Biopsy: Biopsy is contraindicated in suspected JNA due to the high risk of severe bleeding given the vascular nature of the tumor. Attempting a biopsy can lead to significant complications.

 

Educational Objective:


The investigation of choice for diagnosing Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is CECT due to its ability to define the tumor's vascularity and extent while safely avoiding the complications associated with biopsy

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and yellowish-green crusts are present in the nasal cavity. She is found to have merciful anosmia. Which of the following finding can also be seen during the examination of her nose? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roomy nasal cavity

 

ATROPHIC RHINITIS:

 

Pathology - Ciliated columnar epithelium is lost and is replaced by stratified squamous type. There is atrophy of seromucinous glands, venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements. Arteries in the mucosa, periosteum and bone show obliterative endarteritis. The bone of turbinates undergoes resorption causing widening of nasal chambers. Paranasal sinuses are small due to their arrested development.

 

Clinical Features

 

  1. Commonly seen in females and starts around puberty
  2. Foul smell from the nose though the patient himself is unaware of the smell due to marked anosmia (merciful anosmia) which accompanies these degenerative changes.
  3. Patients may complain of nasal obstruction due to large crusts filling the nose.
  4. Epistaxis may occur when the crusts are removed.

 

On examination shows

 

  1. Nasal cavity to be full of greenish or grayish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. Attempts to remove them may cause bleeding.
  2. When the crusts have been removed, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates.
  3. Nasal mucosa appears pale. Septal perforation and dermatitis of nasal vestibule may be present. Nose may show a saddle deformity.
  4.  Atrophic changes may also be seen in the pharyngeal mucosa larynx.
  5. Hearing impairment may be noticed because of obstruction to the eustachian tube and middle ear effusion.
  6. Paranasal sinuses are usually small and underdeveloped with thick walls.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing chloromycetin, estradiol, and vitamin D2.
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.

 

Surgical management:

 

  • Young's operation: In this procedure, flaps are raised within the nasal vestibule and both the nostrils are completely closed and are opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa may revert to normal and the crusting is reduced.
  • Modified young's operation: In this procedure, the nostrils are partially closed and thereby avoiding the discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. The results are the same compared to Young's operation.
  • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal polyps: These are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps.

 

Option C. Inferior turbinate hypertrophy: It is associated with various mucosal diseases which include allergic rhinitis, infectious rhinitis, and vasomotor rhinitis. It can cause chronic nasal obstruction.

 

Option D. Foreign body nose: It is commonly seen in children and the child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis leads to significant structural changes within the nasal cavity, most notably an enlargement of the space due to bone and soft tissue atrophy. Recognizing these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the condition effectively, with treatments often focusing on moisturizing the nasal cavity and addressing the underlying atrophic changes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 172, 173

questions.text: A 14-year-old male is brought to OPD with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. On examination, a mass was observed on left posterior choanae as shown below. What is the management of the patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Surgical excision

 

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Surgical excision will be the management of the patient.

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

  • Most common benign tumor of nasopharynx.
  • Site of origin: sphenopalatine foramen.
  • It is highly vascular tumor. vessels are just endothelium-lined spaces with no elastic or muscle coat. This accounts for the severe bleeding as the vessels lose the ability to contract; also, the bleeding cannot be controlled by application of adrenaline, hence biopsy is contraindicated.

 

Extensions of JNA

 

  1. Nasal cavity causing nasal obstruction, epistaxis and nasal discharge.
  2. Paranasal sinuses. Maxillary, sphenoid and ethmoid sinuses can all be invaded.
  3. Pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa and cheek.
  4. Orbits giving rise to proptosis and “frog-face deformity.” It enters through the inferior orbital fissure and also destroys apex of the orbit. It can also enter the orbit through superior orbital fissure.
  5. Cranial cavity. It can extend into:
  6. Anterior cranial fossa through roof of ethmoids or cribriform plate.
  7. Middle cranial fossa through erosion of floor of middle cranial fossa or indirectly by invading the sphenoid sinus and Sella turcica. In the former case, tumor lies lateral to internal carotid artery and in the latter case medial to the artery

 

Clinical features –

 

  • Adolescent male
  • Profuse spontaneous recurrent epistaxis
  • Nasal obstruction with denasal speech
  • Conductive hearing loss due to tubal block
  • Pink/purple mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features like broadening of nasal bridge, proptosis, swelling of cheek, infratemporal fossa or involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth and VIth cranial nerves will depend on the extent of tumor.

 

Investigation:

 

  1. CECT (contrast enhanced CT) - This shows Hollman miller sign or antral sign i.e., anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus
  2. MRI is complementary to CT scan
  3. Angiography – to assess blood supply of tumor. Feeding vessels should be embolized preoperatively

 

Treatment – Surgical excision is treatment of choice.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology): Not suitable for JNA: Due to the tumor's high vascularity, FNAC could result in significant bleeding and is not typically used for diagnosis or treatment in cases suspected of being JNA.

 

Option B. Biopsy: Risk of severe bleeding: Similar to FNAC, a direct biopsy of JNA is contraindicated due to the risk of triggering severe hemorrhage from the tumor’s vascular structure.

 

Option C. Radiotherapy: Not a primary treatment: While radiotherapy can be considered in certain cases where surgical excision is incomplete or not feasible, it is not the primary treatment method for JNA. The primary approach is surgical removal, given the effectiveness of surgery in achieving control of the tumor and minimizing long-term complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected JNA, especially with the classical presentation of recurrent nosebleeds in adolescent males, prompt referral for imaging and surgical consultation is critical. Surgical excision, following detailed imaging and possibly preoperative embolization, represents the best approach to manage this condition effectively.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother, who is concerned about his nasal-sounding voice. She reports that her son seems to be frequently "talking through his nose," especially when he is trying to pronounce 'm' and 'n' sounds. Additionally, she mentions that he breathes through his mouth most of the time, especially at night, and has been having difficulty sleeping. On examination, the boy has no signs of acute respiratory distress but does have a hyponasal voice. Xray reveals enlarged adenoids obstructing the nasopharynx. No other abnormalities are noted. What type of voice change is most likely present in this patient due to his enlarged adenoids? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhinorrhea clausa

 

Given the context of adenoid enlargement affecting the voice, the most likely associated voice change would be Option A, Rhinolalia clausa, because enlarged adenoids can block the nasal passages and affect the normal resonance of speech.

 

Rhinolalia clausa is characterized by a nasal quality to the voice due to blockage in the nasal passages, which could be caused by enlarged adenoids. This blockage prevents normal resonance in the nasal cavities, leading to a muffled, nasal-sounding voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhinolalia aperta refers to a voice that sounds excessively nasal due to inadequate closure of the velopharyngeal sphincter, usually not directly associated with adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option C. A hot potato voice is typically described as a muffled and garbled voice, as if speaking with a hot potato in the mouth. This is often found in conditions such as a peritonsillar abscess rather than adenoid enlargement.

 

Option D. Echolalia is the repetition of phrases or sounds and is a communication disorder. It is not a type of voice quality and is not related to adenoids or their enlargement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The voice of a patient with enlarged adenoids is likely to exhibit Rhinolalia clausa, characterized by a nasal quality due to obstruction of the nasal passages.

questions.text: A child was brought to OPD with cola colored urine, his mother gives history of odynophagia, dysphagia, fever, and membrane over tonsils as given in image. Which among the following is likely cause?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Streptococcal Tonsillitis

 

Explanation:

 

Streptococcal tonsillitis is characterized by a tenacious exudate that forms a membrane over the tonsils. The image shows a thick, white exudate covering the tonsils, which is typical for streptococcal tonsillitis. This condition can present with symptoms such as fever, odynophagia (painful swallowing), dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), and cola-colored urine (a sign of possible post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Faucial diphtheria: Presents with a thick, grayish membrane that bleeds when removed. It is typically accompanied by significant cervical lymphadenopathy and neck swelling, which is not described in the case.

 

 

Option B. Vincent angina: Also known as acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis, is associated with ulcerations and necrotic areas rather than forming a thick membrane over the tonsils. The description and image do not match this presentation.

 

 

Option D. Oral Candidiasis: Generally presents with widespread white plaques that can be scraped off, revealing red, inflamed tissue underneath. The membrane shown in the image is more localized to the tonsils, which is more characteristic of streptococcal tonsillitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcal tonsillitis can present with a thick, white exudate covering the tonsils, accompanied by fever, painful swallowing, and potential complications such as post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, indicated by cola-colored urine.

questions.text: A post-COVID patient who received prolonged steroid therapy presents with orbital pain, proptosis, and decreased vision. Which investigation would confirm the diagnosis in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MRI

 

The scenario suggests Aspergillus orbital infection (invasive fungal sinusitis). In post-COVID patients who received steroids, Aspergillus is also a significant concern alongside mucormycosis. The clinical presentation of orbital pain, proptosis, and vision loss suggests orbital invasion.

 

MRI is the investigation of choice because:

  1. It can show characteristic "stranding" of orbital fat
  2. Demonstrates hypointense fungal colonies on T2-weighted images
  3. Can detect early perineural spread before clinical manifestation
  4. Shows specific features like the "tram-track sign" of arterial wall enhancement
  5. Better delineates intracranial extension through orbital apex

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CSF fungal culture: While useful in cases with CNS involvement, it has low sensitivity in early disease and is more invasive than necessary for initial diagnosis.

 

Option C. CT scan with contrast: Although helpful in showing bony erosion, it's less sensitive than MRI for soft tissue involvement and perineural spread.

 

Option D. Biopsy of lateral rectus muscle: Unnecessarily invasive as first-line investigation and may risk spreading infection. Additionally, lateral rectus is not typically the first muscle involved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In post-COVID patients with orbital symptoms, early diagnosis of invasive fungal infection is crucial. While both Aspergillus and Mucor can cause similar presentations, MRI characteristics can help differentiate between them and guide appropriate antifungal therapy. The key is recognizing specific imaging patterns that suggest fungal invasion before extensive tissue damage occurs

questions.text: A patient presents with foul-smell from nose and nasal obstruction. The image of the finding is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrophic rhinitis

 

Based on the image showing a significant amount of crusting and given the symptom of foul smell, the most likely diagnosis is Option A, Atrophic rhinitis.

 

Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by a thickening and drying out of the mucous membrane in the nose, leading to crusting, a widened nasal cavity, and a foul smell. The image showing thick, greenish crusts is consistent with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhinitis sicca: Is associated with dryness of the nasal mucosa but without the severe crusting or foul smell typically seen in atrophic rhinitis. It usually does not present with the extent of crusting or debris depicted in the image.

 

Option C. Rhinosporidiosis: Is a chronic infection caused by the organism Rhinosporidium seeberi. It typically presents with polyp-like masses in the nasal passage, which may be friable and bleed easily. The image does not clearly show polyp-like structures, which would be more indicative of this condition.

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis: Is an allergic response causing symptoms like sneezing, itching, and a runny nose, often related to seasonal allergens. It does not cause the thick crusting or the foul smell evident in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of Atrophic Rhinitis is crucial, especially the distinctive symptoms of nasal obstruction and a foul-smelling discharge, along with visible crusting as seen in the provided image. This helps differentiate it from other forms of rhinitis, which do not present with such severe crusting or malodour.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding from the nose, nasal obstruction and difficulty in breathing. He gave the history of bathing in the local pool near his house. On examination, red polypoidal mass with whitish dots on the surface is observed. Based on the history, examination and given histopathological image what would be the diagnosis of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhinosporidiosis

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic infection caused by the aquatic organism Rhinosporidium seeberi. It primarily affects mucous membranes, especially in the nasal passages but also the eyes, ears, and occasionally other areas. Patients typically present with polypoidal masses in the nasal area that can cause bleeding, nasal obstruction, and respiratory difficulty. It is commonly associated with exposure to stagnant water.

Histopathology: Characteristic findings include large, thick-walled sporangia containing numerous endospores, as observed in the provided histopathological image.

Other Options: 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma

Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that commonly appears on sun-exposed areas but can occasionally occur near the nasal region. It typically presents as a nodular lesion with a pearly edge and may have telangiectasias but lacks the distinct histopathology of sporangia with endospores.

Histopathology: Microscopically, it shows nests of basaloid cells with palisading nuclei at the periphery.

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting the respiratory tract. It leads to the formation of hard, sclerotic nodules and masses mainly in the nasal passages.

Histopathology: It is characterized by the presence of Mikulicz cells, which are large foam cells containing the bacteria, and a background of chronic inflammatory cells.

Option D. Lupus Vulgaris

Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis presenting typically on the skin with reddish-brown nodules and plaques that can ulcerate over time. It rarely affects the nasal area directly unless there is disseminated cutaneous involvement.

Histopathology: Shows granulomatous inflammation with caseating necrosis typical of tuberculosis.

Educational Objective:

Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients with nasal masses who have a history of contact with stagnant water bodies, presenting with the characteristic polypoidal mass and sporangia on histopathology.

questions.text: The provided picture shows a patient who has undergone mastoidectomy. Identify the lateral semicircular canal in the image. (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

In the given image of a post-mastoidectomy surgical field, label A corresponds to the lateral semicircular canal. The lateral semicircular canal is a crucial component of the inner ear's vestibular system, involved in maintaining balance and spatial orientation. It can be identified by its specific location relative to other anatomical landmarks visible in the image, such as the tympanic bone, mastoid tip, and the spine of Henle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: This label points to the posterior semicircular canal, which is a bony protrusion in the mastoid portion of the temporal bone, serving as an important landmark during mastoid surgery.

 

Option C: This indicates the sigmoid sinus, a dural venous sinus within the skull, lying beneath the cranial bone and above the structures of the middle and inner ear.

 

Option D: Labelled as the Tegmen, which is part of the temporal bone that forms the roof over the middle ear and mastoid antrum, shielding these structures from the intracranial contents.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The lateral semicircular canal, identified at label A, is part of the vestibular system, crucial for balance and orientation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient arrives at the OPD with a concern about her ability to perceive speech sounds while struggling to comprehend the actual words being spoken. Her Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) and Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) results show discrepancies, as the PTA is relatively within the normal range. However, her mid-latency and cortical responses are both non-existent. What probable diagnosis can be inferred from these findings? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auditory neuropathy

 

If a child arrives with concerns about not being able to comprehend words, and their BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) results are abnormal while their PTA (Pure Tone Audiometry) results are normal, this could indicate the presence of auditory neuropathy.

 

Auditory neuropathy is a neurologic disorder of CN VIII. Audiometric tests, e.g. SNHL for pure tones, impaired speech discrimination score, absent or abnormal auditory brainstem response, show a retrocochlear type of lesion but OAEs are normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Michel aplasia also known as complete labyrinthine aplasia, is the most severe congenital inner ear malformation, characterized by complete absence of inner ear structures. This condition would present with profound hearing loss detected on PTA, not normal PTA results.

 

Option C. Malingering: Intentional falsification of hearing loss would likely be exposed by objective tests like BERA, which would not show the abnormal results observed in this case.

 

Option D. Cochlear otosclerosis shows Carhart’s notch (dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction) on PTA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auditory neuropathy should be suspected in patients who present with normal hearing sensitivity on pure tone audiometry but show significant difficulties with speech comprehension and abnormal brainstem evoked response audiometry results.

questions.text: A patient presents with a fluctuant, tender swelling below the mastoid tip extending into the upper neck as shown in the image. What could be the diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bezold abscess

 

Bezold's abscess is a rare but serious complication of acute mastoiditis where pus breaks through the mastoid tip and tracks down into the neck along the posterior belly of digastric and sternocleidomastoid muscles. Key diagnostic features include:

 

  1. Swelling extending from mastoid tip to upper neck
  2. History of ear discharge/mastoid pain preceding neck swelling
  3. Tenderness along sternocleidomastoid muscle
  4. Limited neck movement
  5. Associated signs of mastoiditis (post-auricular tenderness, outward protrusion of pinna)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parotid abscess: Typically presents as swelling anterior to ear over parotid region, not extending below mastoid tip.

 

Option C. Deep neck space infection: More diffuse involvement of neck spaces, usually without specific relation to mastoid tip.

 

Option D. Infected branchial cyst: Usually presents along anterior border of sternocleidomastoid, not related to mastoid tip.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the anatomical pathway of Bezold's abscess is crucial for diagnosis. Pus breaking through the mastoid tip follows a specific path along muscle planes, creating a characteristic clinical picture. Early recognition is important as it requires both mastoid surgery and neck exploration for adequate drainage

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in given endoscopic view of the nasal cavity:(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior turbinate

 

Marked structure is Inferior turbinate.

 

  • Inferior turbinate is a separate bone, arranged longitudinally.
  • Attaches anteriorly with maxilla and posteriorly with palatine bone.
  • Also attached to lacrimal bone and uncinate process of ethmoid in between.
  • Over the bone, thick vascular mucosal tissue surrounds.
  • The vascular channels travel from posterior to anterior inside the turbinate mucosa, so that inspired air will be in exchange of moisture (humidification of inspired air) with vascular channels for a long duration.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Middle turbinate: This is located above the inferior turbinate and is part of the ethmoid bone. It plays a role in directing air flow and protecting sinus openings.

 

Option C. Superior turbinate: The smallest of the turbinates, located higher up in the nasal cavity and also part of the ethmoid bone.

 

Option D. Uncinate process: This is a part of the ethmoid bone that forms the anterior border of the hiatus semilunaris, involved in the drainage pathway of the sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inferior turbinate is a critical structure for the proper conditioning of air entering the respiratory system. Its large surface area and vascular mucosa play essential roles in the humidification and warming of inhaled air, contributing to the overall respiratory health and protection against pathogens and particulate matter.

questions.text: A 5-year-old presents with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice over three months and respiratory distress for 2 weeks. Diagnosis is: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory papillomatosis

 

The given clinical situation suggests that the child is suffering from respiratory papillomatosis.

 

Respiratory Papillomatosis (Juvenile Papillomatosis)

 

  • It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is caused by HPV 6 and 11.
  • Involves supraglottic and glottic regions of larynx.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Age 3-5 years
  • Hoarseness or aphonia
  • Respiratory difficulty
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy

 

 

Treatment consists of cold steel/ coblation/ debrider/ radiofrequency/ Laser assisted microlaryngeal surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Croup: Though croup affects young children and presents with respiratory symptoms, it is an acute condition that generally presents rapidly with a characteristic barking cough and stridor, not gradually as in this case.

 

Option C. Vocal nodule: Vocal nodules result from vocal cord trauma and present symmetrically on the free edge of the vocal cords at the junction of the anterior one-third and the posterior two-thirds. They typically cause hoarseness but do not lead to respiratory distress, as they do not obstruct the airway.

 

Option D. Acute epiglottitis: This is another acute condition, presenting with rapid onset and severe symptoms including high fever, throat pain, and significant respiratory distress. The progressive nature of the symptoms described in the question does not align with the acute presentation of epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Juvenile respiratory papillomatosis should be considered in young children presenting with a gradual worsening of hoarseness and the development of respiratory symptoms. The condition highlights the need for awareness of HPV-related diseases in children and indicates the importance of early and accurate diagnosis followed by appropriate surgical intervention, which may include cold steel, coblation, debrider, radiofrequency, or laser-assisted microlaryngeal surgery to manage the growth and recurrence of papillomas effectively.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 327, 328, 343, 345, 346

choices.text: Topical antibiotics and decongestants for 4 weeks
IV antibiotics and follow up after a month

questions.text: A child presents with foul-smelling ear discharge. On further exploration, a small perforation is found in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane as shown below. Most appropriate management would be: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tympanomastoid exploration

 

The child presents with foul-smelling ear discharge and a small perforation in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane, indicating an attic perforation. This condition is consistent with attico-antral chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), also known as unsafe CSOM. This type of CSOM is characterized by scanty, mucopurulent, foul-smelling discharge, which may sometimes be bloodstained.

 

The definitive management for attico-antral CSOM is tympanomastoid exploration. This procedure helps to eradicate the disease from the middle ear and mastoid, preventing further complications such as cholesteatoma and hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical antibiotics and decongestants for 4 weeks: While topical antibiotics can be used to manage the discharge and infection initially, they are not the definitive treatment for attico-antral CSOM. The primary goal is to control the infection, but definitive surgical intervention is required for complete management.
