Option B. IV antibiotics and follow up after a month: IV antibiotics may be used in severe cases to control acute infection, but they are not the standard approach for managing attico-antral CSOM. Follow-up after a month without addressing the underlying condition is not adequate.

 

Option C. Tympanoplasty: Tympanoplasty is a surgical procedure aimed at repairing the tympanic membrane and is typically used in cases of safe CSOM or tubotympanic CSOM. It is not appropriate for attico-antral CSOM, where more extensive surgical intervention is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Attico-antral CSOM, characterized by foul-smelling discharge and attic perforation, requires tympanomastoid exploration for definitive management.

questions.text: Water's view is used to best visualize which of the following sinuses? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinus

 

Waters’ view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position). The X-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line.

 

In this view, petrous bones are projected below the maxillary antra.

 

Structures seen are:

 

  1. Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  2. Frontal sinuses
  3. Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth).
  4. Zygoma
  5. Zygomatic arch
  6. Nasal bone.
  7. Frontal process of maxilla
  8. Superior orbital fissure
  9. Intratemporal fossa.

 

Other 3 Options: Not best visualized in Water's view as this technique primarily highlights the maxillary and other larger sinuses.
 

Educational Objective:
 

Water's view is particularly effective for visualizing the maxillary sinus, making it an essential diagnostic tool in sinus imaging, especially when evaluating issues related to the maxillary sinuses.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

questions.text: A 35-year-old scuba diver presents with ear fullness and hearing loss immediately after surfacing. The otoscopic finding is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumotympanum

 

The image shows fluid or blood behind the tympanic membrane, and given the patient's history of scuba diving and symptoms of ear fullness and hearing loss, the most likely diagnosis is:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serous otitis media: This presents with a yellowish fluid behind the tympanic membrane but lacks the history of pressure change or hemorrhage.

 

 

Option C. Hemotympanum: This involves blood behind the tympanic membrane, but the presence of bubbles and the history of diving points toward barotrauma as the underlying cause.

 

 

Option D. Barotrauma with middle ear hemorrhage:

 

  • History: Scuba diving is a risk factor for barotrauma due to changes in pressure.
  • Findings: The image suggests blood (hemorrhage) and possible fluid accumulation in the middle ear. The tympanic membrane appears reddish with visible bubbles or blood behind it.
  • Barotrauma Pathophysiology: During ascent or descent in diving, rapid pressure changes can cause damage to the middle ear if equalization (via the Eustachian tube) fails. This can lead to rupture of small blood vessels and accumulation of blood or fluid.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understand the pathophysiology and otoscopic findings of middle ear barotrauma, a condition caused by pressure changes during activities like scuba diving. Learn to recognize symptoms such as ear fullness, hearing loss, and hemorrhage behind the tympanic membrane, and differentiate it from similar conditions. Focus on prevention, symptomatic management, and when to seek specialized care.

questions.text:
Which of the following tests can be used if otoacoustic emissions is absent for screening?(INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Pure tone audiometry
  2. Tympanometry
  3. Free field audiometry
  4. Speech audiometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 4

 

When otoacoustic emissions (OAE) are absent, it indicates a potential cochlear pathology, specifically affecting the outer hair cells. Further testing is required to assess the extent and nature of hearing loss, as well as to rule out any retrocochlear pathology.

 

2. Tympanometry: This test assesses the condition of the middle ear and tympanic membrane mobility by creating variations in air pressure in the ear canal. It is useful to determine if the absence of OAEs might be related to middle ear issues, such as fluid, which can mask cochlear function.

 

4. Speech Audiometry: This test evaluates the ability to understand speech and also provides information about the clarity of speech perception. It helps to determine the speech recognition threshold and is crucial for diagnosing the degree and type of hearing loss when OAEs are absent.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Pure Tone Audiometry: While this test is crucial for determining the threshold levels of hearing and the degree of hearing loss across different frequencies, it was not specified as one of the correct responses in this context.

 

3. Free Field Audiometry: Generally used for young children or individuals who cannot reliably use headphones, this test measures hearing sensitivity to sounds presented in an open field. However, it requires a controlled sound field, which is not always practical for immediate follow-up when OAEs are absent.

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 29

questions.text: An adult patient presents with acute respiratory distress during dinner. They are unable to speak but can cough weakly. What is the most appropriate immediate intervention? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Back blows

 

In partial airway obstruction with ineffective cough (weak cough, increased breathing difficulty, unable to speak), the first line intervention is to deliver 5 sharp back blows between the shoulder blades. This follows current resuscitation guidelines for foreign body airway obstruction (FBAO).

 

The rationale for back blows as first-line treatment:

 

  1. Less traumatic than abdominal thrusts
  2. Can be performed immediately without positioning delays
  3. Utilizes gravity along with percussion force
  4. Can be alternated with chest thrusts if needed
  5. Lower risk of internal organ injury

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heimlich's maneuver: While effective, it's considered second-line after back blows in partial obstruction. Reserved for complete obstruction or if back blows fail.

 

Option C. Head-tilt chin-lift: Used in unconscious patients for airway opening, not appropriate for foreign body obstruction in conscious patients.

 

Option D. Lateral abdominal thrusts: Not a standard technique and may be less effective than traditional anteriorly directed thrusts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the stepwise approach to foreign body airway obstruction is crucial. Current guidelines emphasize starting with back blows in partial obstruction with ineffective cough, progressing to abdominal thrusts only if back blows are unsuccessful. This approach maximizes effectiveness while minimizing the risk of complications.

questions.text: Pott's puffy tumor is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone

 

  • Pott's puffy tumor is the subperiosteal abscess of the frontal bone.
  • Pott puffy tumor is a soft doughy forehead swelling due to frontal bone osteomyelitis with associated subperiosteal abscess. PPT is a rare complication of frontal sinusitis, but can also occur due to trauma.
  • It is more often seen in adults as frontal sinus is not developed in infants and children.
  • The pathophysiology for the development of frontal skull osteomyelitis can occur due to hematogenous spread of the infection or to direct extension of infection.
  • Presents with tender forehead swelling associated with fever, headaches, nasal discharge, or symptoms of increased intracranial pressure
  • Treatment consists of large doses of antibiotics, drainage of abscess and trephining of frontal sinus through its floor. Sometimes, it requires removal of sequestra and necrotic bone by raising a scalp flap through a coronal incision

 

 

Complications of frontal sinusitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subperiosteal abscess of ethmoid bone: Incorrect, as the ethmoid bone typically presents with other orbital or intranasal complications.

 

Option C. Mucocele of frontal bone: Incorrect, as mucoceles refer to mucus-filled cysts resulting from blocked sinus ducts, not infections.

 

Option D. Mucocele of ethmoid bone: Also incorrect and refers to a different pathological condition involving the ethmoid sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pott's puffy tumor is a severe and rare complication of frontal sinusitis, presenting with distinctive forehead swelling and potentially grave complications. Prompt diagnosis and comprehensive treatment are crucial to prevent further spread of infection and ensure recovery.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 224

questions.text: An individual who is experiencing vertigo but does not have hearing impairment has consulted an ENT surgeon. The surgeon proceeds with a diagnostic technique followed by a carefully executed therapeutic procedure. What is the diagnostic maneuver?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dix-Hallpike maneuver

 

Vertigo without hearing loss diagnosed by a positional maneuver is benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The diagnostic maneuver used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver and therapeutic maneuver is the Epley's maneuver.

 

Dix-Hallpike maneuver:

 

  • Gold standard for diagnosing BPPV. 
  •  Nystagmus has a short latency period of 2-20 seconds, lasts for less than a minute, and has a fixed direction towards the lower placed ear, and is fatigable.
  • Associated with vertigo.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hampton's maneuver: This is not a widely recognized or standard maneuver in the diagnosis or treatment of vertigo. It does not relate to any commonly accepted procedure in the management of vertigo in otolaryngology.

 

Option C. Epley's maneuver: The therapeutic maneuver is the Epley maneuver which repositions the otolith to the utricle/saccule from the posterior semicircular canal.

 

 

Option D. Simon's maneuver: Like Hampton's maneuver, Simon's maneuver is not a standard or widely recognized technique in the diagnosis or management of vertigo associated with BPPV or other inner ear conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is specifically used for diagnosing BPPV by eliciting nystagmus induced by position changes.
  • The Epley's maneuver is used to treat the vertigo symptoms once BPPV is confirmed by the Dix-Hallpike test.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 47

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and bleeding. After diagnosis, it is determined to be inverted papilloma. What is the correct description of this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Benign and locally invasive

 

Inverted papilloma, also known as Schneiderian papilloma or Transitional cell papilloma, is characterized by its benign nature but with a propensity for local invasiveness. This type of tumor arises from the epithelial lining of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses and is notable for its tendency to grow inward into the underlying stroma rather than outward.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A & D. Malignant/Malignant and locally invasive: These are incorrect as inverted papilloma is primarily benign, though it requires aggressive management due to its invasive nature.

 

Option C. Benign and non-invasive: This is incorrect because, although benign, inverted papillomas are distinctly characterized by their local invasiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inverted papilloma is a benign but locally invasive tumor primarily affecting the nasal cavity, requiring aggressive surgical management due to its invasive characteristics and potential complications. Regular follow-up is crucial due to the risk of recurrence and rare malignant transformation.

questions.text: Which of these labeled structures represents a division of the internal carotid artery? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

The structure marked 1 and 4 are the anterior ethmoidal artery and posterior ethmoidal artery, which are branches of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vascular Supply of the Nasal Cavity:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: A 60-year-old individual with diabetes presented with intense ear pain and otorrhea that did not improve with antibiotics. During the examination, granulation tissue was observed in the external auditory canal (EAC), and the person also exhibited facial nerve palsy. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Malignant otitis externa

 

Severe otalgia in an elderly diabetic patient with granulation tissue in the external ear canal points to a diagnosis of Malignant (Necrotizing) otitis externa.

 

ETIOLOGY – More common in elderly, diabetic and immunocompromised patients.

 

CAUSATIVE ORGANISM - Pseudomonas aeruginosa (most common), Staphylococcus aureus, Proteus species, and fungi.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES

 

  • Excruciating ear pain
  • Granulations in the ear canal
  • Facial paralysis is common.
  • Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple lower cranial nerve palsies
  • Anteriorly, infection spreads to temporomandibular fossa
  • Posteriorly to the mastoid and medially into the middle ear and petrous bone.

 

DIAGNOSIS

 

  • Gallium-67 is more useful in diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. It is taken up by monocytes and reticuloendothelial cells, and is indicative of soft tissue infection. It can be repeated every 3 weeks to monitor the disease and response to treatment.          
  • Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection but test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease.

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Control of diabetes
  • Aural toilet
  • Antibiotic treatment against causative organism, which in most commonly P. aeruginosa (or any other causative organism) for 6-8 weeks.
  • Antibiotics commonly used are anti-pseudomonal antibiotics ; Third-generation cephalosporins ; Ciprofloxacin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otomycosis: Typically presents with itching and a fungal ear discharge, without the severe pain or systemic complications seen in MOE.

 

Option B. Serous otitis media: Involves fluid accumulation in the middle ear, generally without the severe external ear pain or granulation tissue.

 

Option D. Eczematous otitis externa: Characterized by itching and skin changes, but not the deep infection or severe complications associated with MOE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignant otitis externa is a critical condition requiring aggressive management due to its potential to cause widespread damage and severe complications, including cranial nerve involvement. Prompt and appropriate treatment is essential to prevent potentially life-threatening outcomes.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 55

questions.text: A teenager has a mass in his nasopharynx that has minimally spread into the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension. Which stage of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma could this be?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage IB

 

According to Radkowski, the staging system mass in the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension, indicates Stage IB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IA: This stage involves tumors limited to the nose and/or nasopharynx, without any extension into the sinuses.

 

Option C. Stage IIA: Describes minimal extension into the pterygopalatine fossa, which is not indicated in this patient.

 

Option D. Stage IIB: Indicates occupation of the entire pterygopalatine fossa with or without erosion of the orbital apex, which also does not apply to this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

THE RADKOWSKI STAGING SYSTEM FOR JUVENILE NASOPHARYNGEAL ANGIOFIBROMA

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with epistaxis. There was no relief on pinching the nostrils. Nasal packing was done but the patient still continues to bleed. What would be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ligation of sphenopalatine artery

 

Sphenopalatine artery ligation should be considered in cases where epistaxis is not controlled by trotters method or nasal packing.

 

Ligation should be performed as close as possible to the likely bleeding point.

 

Most common artery to be ligated for epistaxis is Sphenopalatine artery followed by internal maxillary artery, External carotid artery, Anterior /posterior ethmoidal artery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligation of external carotid artery: The external carotid artery is a major artery that supplies blood to numerous facial structures, including the scalp, face, jaw, and more. Ligation of this artery is generally considered a more drastic measure and is typically reserved for severe cases where other specific arterial sources of bleeding have been ruled out or are inaccessible. It is much less selective than targeting the sphenopalatine artery and can lead to significant complications due to reduced blood flow to essential tissues.

 

Option B. Ligation of internal carotid artery: This option is generally not considered for epistaxis management due to the critical nature of the internal carotid artery, which primarily supplies blood to the brain. Ligation of this artery would pose a high risk of serious neurological deficits or stroke. It is a major artery and not a contributor to nasal bleeding; thus, it is not targeted in the treatment of epistaxis.

 

Option D. Ligation of maxillary artery: The maxillary artery is a major artery within the face that branches off the external carotid artery and gives rise to the sphenopalatine artery. While ligation of the maxillary artery is an option for severe epistaxis, it is less specific than targeting the sphenopalatine artery. The maxillary artery supplies areas broader than just the nasal cavity, including the maxilla, mandible, teeth, and parts of the face. Therefore, ligation of this artery is considered more invasive and has a higher risk of complications compared to the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sphenopalatine artery ligation is a highly effective surgical procedure for controlling severe or refractory epistaxis after more conservative measures have failed. This approach targets a primary blood supply to the nasal cavity, significantly reducing the risk of further bleeding.

questions.text: A patient presented with vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt. He underwent myringoplasty for the safe type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) 6 months back. What is your diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perilymphatic fistula

 

  • The clinical scenario with symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt and history of myringoplasty done for CSOM suggest that the diagnosis is perilymphatic fistula.
  • A peri-lymphatic fistula is an abnormal communication between the inner ear and the middle ear that can allow perilymph to leak from the cochlea or vestibule, most commonly through the round or oval window.
  • Precipitating causes include surgery, blunt trauma, penetrating trauma, barotrauma, infection, cholesteatoma, or sudden changes in CSF pressure as can occur with straining, sneezing, or Valsalva’s maneuver. Congenital ear abnormalities may predispose to perilymph leaks. Spontaneous perilymph fistulae are rare.
  • The clinical picture of perilymph fistulae is variable, with symptoms ranging from mild to incapacitating. Vertigo, or more often unsteadiness, is the most common symptom. Hearing loss, tinnitus, or aural fullness may be present. A thorough history inquiring about activities such as trauma, scuba diving, flying, and straining is critical in the diagnosis of this disorder as the symptoms are vague and coincident with other vestibular disorders. Fistula test is positive.

 

Investigations

 

  • HRCT temporal bone has high sensitivity in detecting peri lymphatic fistula.
  • A combination of CT and MRI diagnose almost 100% of cases.
  • Other tests include audiometry and electrocochleography.

 

Management of a peri-lymphatic fistula is either by conservative or surgical methods. Conservative therapy includes avoiding anything that can increase inner ear or intracranial pressure and the use of intratympanic steroids in acute decompensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labyrinthitis presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sweating and pallor and sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Option C. Paget's disease of bone usually presents with hearing loss as a prominent feature, when the skull is involved. It is not associated with a history of surgery, trauma or vestibulocochlear symptoms.

 

Option D. Vestibular Schwannoma, also called as acoustic neuroma is a tumor that arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular, but rarely from the cochlear division of vestibulocochlear nerve within the internal auditory canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perilymphatic fistula should be suspected in patients presenting with vestibular symptoms following ear surgery, particularly when associated with activities that change intracranial or middle ear pressure. Diagnosis is largely based on clinical history, symptomatology, and specific imaging tests.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo associated with horizontal nystagmus. The slow component is towards the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left hypoactive labyrinth

 

  • A left hypoactive labyrinth is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features.
  • Vestibular nystagmus has a slow and fast component.
  • The fast component denotes the direction of the nystagmus.
  • Paretic lesions such as purulent labyrinthitis, and trauma to the labyrinth cause nystagmus to the healthy side.
  • Serous labyrinthitis (irritative lesion) leads to nystagmus on the same side of the lesion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior canal BPPV: Characterized by positional vertigo and typically vertical nystagmus, related to the posterior semicircular canal.

 

Option B. Superior canal BPPV: Also known as anterior canal BPPV, would cause primarily vertically oriented nystagmus, not horizontal.

 

Option C. Right hypoactive labyrinth: Would produce nystagmus with the slow component towards the right and the fast component towards the left, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The direction of the slow and fast components of nystagmus is crucial in diagnosing the affected side in vestibular disorders. A left hypoactive labyrinth leads to nystagmus with a fast component to the right, matching the clinical presentation in this scenario.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 43

questions.text: Foreign body entry into the laryngeal inlet is prevented by the cough reflex. This reflex is sluggish in alcohol ingestion and some other conditions. Which nerve is likely injured?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal laryngeal nerve

 

Cough reflex is a protective mechanism of the larynx to expel foreign irritants in order to keep airway clear. Afferent of this reflex is through internal laryngeal nerve, which gives sensory supply to mucosa above vocal cords. Irritant substances like alcohol affects the nervous system causing inhibition of cough reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Primarily involved in the sensation and taste on the posterior one-third of the tongue, not directly involved in the cough reflex at the larynx.

 

Option C. External laryngeal nerve: Mainly supplies the cricothyroid muscle with motor fibers and does not have a sensory role in the cough reflex.

 

Option D. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: Supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid and provides sensory innervation to the mucosa below the vocal cords; thus, it plays a role in the cough reflex but primarily for the lower part of the larynx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to or inhibition of the internal laryngeal nerve can significantly impair the cough reflex by reducing the sensory input required to detect irritants above the vocal cords, emphasizing its pivotal role in this protective reflex.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 337
